intro: Galium petraeum var. virgatum, commonly known as the Virginia bedstraw, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, creeping stems and small, opposite leaves. The plant produces clusters of tiny, white or pale yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its hairy stems and leaves are often mistaken for other similar species within the genus Galium.
